hints_html: What is the dimension of A? What does the ; do when entering a matrix? Is the output a column or a row vector?
hints_latex:
What is the dimension of \emph{A}? What does the \textbf{;} do when
entering a matrix? Is the output a column or a row vector?
hints_raw: What is the dimension of ''A''? What does the ''';''' do when entering a matrix? Is the output a column or a row vector?
question: A 14
sols_html:
The first line of code creates a 2x3 matrix with the row vector [1 2 3] as its first row and the row vector [4 5 6] as its second row. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} A = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

The second line tells MATLAB to return a vector of all entries in A that have a second argument 1, hence A(1,1) and A(2,1). This is a column vector. Therefore the final answer is

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 4 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The first line of code creates a ''2''x''3'' matrix with the row vector [1 2 3] as its first row and the row vector [4 5 6] as its second row. Hence

:<math> A = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \end{array}\right] </math>

The second line tells MATLAB to return a vector of all entries in ''A'' that have a second argument ''1'', hence ''A(1,1)'' and ''A(2,1)''. This is a column vector. Therefore the final answer is

:<math> \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 4 \end{array}\right] </math>
statement_html:
What is the output after the following lines of MATLAB code?

A = [1 2 3; 4 5 6];
A(:,1)
statement_latex:
What is the output after the following lines of MATLAB code?

\texttt{A~=~{[}1~2~3;~4~5~6{]};}\\\texttt{A(:,1)}
